title: Improving Noise Robustness of LLM-based Zero-shot TTS via Discrete Acoustic Token Denoising
author: Ye-Xin Lu (National Engineering Research Center of Speech and Language Information Processing, University of Science and Technology of China), Hui-Peng Du, Fei Liu, Yang Ai, Zhen-Hua Ling
relevance_why: The paper discusses zero-shot text-to-speech synthesis and noise robustness, which are significant topics within speech technology that align with Haohe Liu's interests in audio enhancement and synthesis.
background: Zero-shot text-to-speech synthesis aims to generate a speaker's voice based on a short audio sample without prior training data for that speaker.
contribution: This paper introduces a codec denoiser that enhances noisy audio prompts at the discrete acoustic token level to achieve noise-robust text-to-speech synthesis, improving speech quality.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods typically rely on speech enhancement models at the signal level, which can introduce artifacts and increase computational complexity.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves on these methods by directly denoising discrete acoustic tokens, reducing noise sensitivity and computational cost while maintaining speech quality.

key_innovation: Utilizes a novel system architecture that operates at the token level rather than the signal level, enabling more effective noise reduction in speech synthesis.
real_world_impact: This approach could significantly enhance the usability of TTS systems in real-world noisy environments, enabling better accessibility for users in diverse situations.
limitations: The paper does not mention any specific limitations but acknowledges the inherent challenges in speech synthesis from noisy inputs.

new_terms.zero-shot TTS: **Zero-shot text-to-speech synthesis** refers to the ability to synthesize speech from a speaker's voice using minimal audio samples without prior training on that speaker's data.
new_terms.discrete acoustic tokens: **Discrete acoustic tokens** are the representations of audio inputs that capture significant speech features, used as an intermediary in synthesized speech processing.
